“Don’t Analyze Graphs?”

Yes..well no…well kinda. DAG stands for Directed Acyclic Graph, simply put it is a graph that is directed and acyclic. Okay, that’s not much of an explanation. To explain it a bit further before adding any images (there will be lots of pictures this post, yippee!), a DAG is a great way to depict how your variables are related. To quote Miguel Hernan, since I couldn’t have put it better myself, “Draw your assumptions before your conclusions”.

In this post, we’re going to go over the basics of DAGs, however this isn’t meant to encompass all aspects of causal diagrams. More of a “wetting your beak” if you will. There will be future posts that will build upon this. Without further ado, let’s get into it.

Assumptions of DAGs

The causal Markov assumption, implies that in a causal DAG, the common causes of any pair of variables must also be in the graph. The willingness to consider a causal diagram for an observational study is the graphical version of the conditional exchangeability assumption:

given \(L, Y^a \perp A|L\)

Rules of DAGs

There are some basic rules of DAGs. We call these d-seperation (Hernan and Robins 2021, 76) :

  1. If no variables are being conditioned on (aka included in our model), a path is blocked if and only if two arrowheads on the path collide at some variable on the path. (that variable is known as a collider)

  2. Any path than contains a non-collider that has been conditioned on is blocked. We show this by putting a square box around a variable to indicate we are conditioning on it.

  3. A collider that has been conditioned on does not block a path.

  4. A collider that has a descendant that has been conditioned on does not block a path.

We can summarize it like this: a path is blocked if and only if, it contains a non-collider that has been conditioned on, or contains a collider that hasn’t been conditioned on and ha sno descendants that have been conditioned on.

Why do we need a DAG?

Before we get started into what it actually is and the rules, it’s always a good idea to review the why.

(can ref/talk about riley2022 12 days of christmas statisitician article)

Simple DAG

“Think of Water Flowing in a Pipe”….What?

One of the peskiest biases

Title ideas (from ChatGPT)

Sure, how about “Don’t Analyze Graphs”? It’s a bit tongue-in-cheek, implying that you should just trust the Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) without over-analyzing it. Of course, in reality, careful analysis is often necessary to ensure the accuracy and validity of DAGs used in various applications such as machine learning.

How about “Dramatic Action Graph”? It’s not necessarily hilarious, but it adds a bit of flair to the otherwise technical-sounding term DAG!

References

Hernan, M. A., and J. M. Robins. 2021. “What If - Causal Inference.” Textbook.
